content.description:
This route is located just right of "Boy I Gotta Go 5.9".  It starts in a large right facing dihedral.

The climb starts with fun stemming and edging.  The crux moves come at the bulge with well spaced finger pockets.  The climb finishes at a set of anchors just right of the 5.9 to the left.

Boulder the mini-crux off the ground over the mini-roof and then romp up the slab.  Work on the right set-up moves into the roof for the lip encounter.  Once your feet are above the lip, relax, get a stance and clip those anchors.  Possibly a tad harder than 10b, or just a good stout 10b.
content.location: The middle of Scud Wall, obvious lower and upper roofs define the root.  Just right of Duck Soup (5.9).

content.description:
This climb is located on the right side of the Scud area, just right of Rubber Soul.  There is a low awkward crux at the second bolt.  The rest of the moves are positive and in the low 5.10 range.

A good route to avoid the crowds on the main Scud wall.

Super fun must do route on Scud wall. This route starts directly left of 'Duck Soup'. Follow bolts on fairly easy climbing (5.9) to the base of the roof. Follow the outer edge of the overhang getting good lie-backs and heel hooks (5.10ish). There is an interesting story regarding this climb. A mysterious climber in a dinosaur onesie managed to climb the route only to get stuck at the chains while trying to rappel. I was forced to lead to the top and rescue this majestic beast. He proceeded to buy me lunch in Lander.
content.protection: Follow bolts to chains at the top of the overhang. I brought 12 draws for good measure.
content.location: The bolted line directly left of 'Duck Soup'.

content.description: Short but very fun overhanging pocket fest. There are bolted 5.11a variations on either side. A little bouldery off the ground.
content.location: Rightmost route (3 routes with variations) on Scud wall.

content.description: This route is located on the far right side of the Scud area, just right of the two 5.7's.  It is a fun outing on continuous thin climbing.  Climb to the left of a left leaning bulge, and work right for the crux moves.  Then follow easier rock to a set of anchors.

Towards right side of crag. Start by climbing the obvious 10ft boulder to reach the first bolt at ~15 ft. Easily identified as the route follows the slabby dihedral. Merges at the top and shares chains with the 5.7 to the right of it.

Start by climbing decent edges to the third bolt and then climb through a thin, hard to read section past the fourth bolt to easier climbing. You might find the climbing smooth or find it heinous - a bit like J. Bieb's songs.
content.location: The route is located on the Scud Wall in the middle of Doggin' Dude and Banoffee. The climb follows a prominent black streak.

content.description:
Start behind a tree. Move up and left into a small right-facing corner. Move up through a huge flake. It looked sketchy but felt solid. Finish over a small roof.

I though the bolts were placed very awkwardly far to the right. The rating is supposedly 10d, but it felt more like 10a/b to me.
content.location: Right of Bombs Over Crag Bag, left of Rubber Soul, and behind a tree

content.description:
A long overlooked route that turned out to be a great addition to the popular Scud Wall.

Start on small pockets and dance up nice black rock until you reach a seam. Follow the seam on side pulls, jugs, and flakes until the last bolt. Trend up and left to the anchor. Continuous challenging sections make for a really fun moderate.
content.protection: 7 glue in bolts to Climbtech hooks. The hardware store bolt near the ground is a DRU (Dog Retention Unit)
content.location: Left of Smithereens at the Scud Wall. Starts on dark rock to the right of a Juniper Tree.

content.description: A fun route with some varied climbing and some steep upper climbing for a 5.9.  Do a flexible move to get established on the slab and romp up a fun flake (reinforced with bolts) as the rock steepens.  Climb big wandering pockets, trending left, as the angle kicks just past vertical near the anchors on big holds.  May be 9+ for the shorter folks.
content.location: Located in the middle left section of the wall, immediately left of Stud Alert (10b)- which has the small roof just off the ground and the distinct roof near its top.

content.description: Nice and long with a good variety of pockets, ledges, and flakes.
content.location: The right of two slab routes just right of the big corner.

content.description: Straight up on edges to increasingly larger pockets.  Another good moderate for the area.
content.location: Starts about 10 feet left of Banoffee, just left of a small dead tree on a small ledge.

content.description:
This route is a popular warm up route in the area.  The rock is quite polished,  but the moves are still fun.

Follow a left leaning flake to series of positive pockets along an arete.  There are a handful of reachy moves found along the way to a bolt anchor.
Layback a flake system to pockets through varied rock quality on a consistently vertical wall.
content.protection: 9 bolts to a 2 bolt ring anchor
content.location: 15 ft. right of Girls Day Out

content.description: Another fine 10a.  Climb straight up on pockets and edges through a large area of whiter rock.  The first bolt is a little high and the start boasts a narrow sloping ledge.
content.location: Near the west edge of the Scud Area, climbs through an obvious section of whiter rock about 20 feet up.

content.description: Up pockets and seam, traverses left-ish.  Anchors are in line with Climb Like A Girl - though you can clip one draw here and continue to 2nd anchors over the small roof above (another 10 feet or so)
content.location: Just left of the prow route, "Boy, I Gotta Go"

climbs.name: A Very Good Place to Start

content.description: Fun combination of lieback flakes and pockets with a short crux before the anchors.
content.location: Located between two trees at the beginning left side of Scud Wall.

content.description: Sparse edges and pockets make for some tough clips. Probably the third clip is the crux, now that there is another bolt added at the start (used to be second clip crux).
content.location: Right of Stud Alert, ends under the big roof. A second anchor has been added above the roof.
